newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugo government plans to sell four Lear jets-paper.
newsitem.headline: Yugo government plans to sell four Lear jets-paper.

text.p: The Yugoslav government plans to sell four of its six Lear-jet 25s, the Belgrade daily Vecernje Novosti said Tuesday.
"We are waiting for a decision from (Prime Minister Radoje) Kontic's cabinet to start with the sale," director of the government air service Bosko Cvijic was quoted as saying.
The price of the planes, now nearly 20 years old, will range from $500,000 to $800,000 and there are many interested buyers from Europe, America and the country, Cvijic said.
He said the service would sell the planes as a package and not individually.

According to Cvijic, the main reason for their sale is the noise made by the jet engines which are banned from landing in Austria and Switzerland and fined $200-$500 for each landing at other airports.
No-one from the government was immediately available for comment.
